oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Opry Star Spotlight - Tex Ritter and Ralph Emery - WSM
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: First recording contains excerpts from an Opry Star Spotlight radio program featuring interviews with Tex Ritter on radio station WSM (Nashville, Tenn.) Interviews conducted by Ralph Emery. Second recording is KVOO (Tulsa, Okla.) radio program of Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band. Originally broadcast 1948. Sponsored by Gates tires, with announcer Johnny Ryan. Third recording is KVOO (Tulsa, Okla.) radio program of Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band. Originally broadcast 1952.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Tex Ritter; Johnny Ryan; Leon McAuliffe; Western Swing Band (Leon McAuliffe)
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Test tones -- Tex Ritter talks about the first album he made after joining Capitol Records -- Ralph Emery talks -- Ritter talks about building the album and covering other people's tunes -- Ritter says how all the recordings are original recordings -- Ralph Emery plays a song off the album -- Boll Weevil (Tex Ritter) [record excerpt] -- Ralph Emery asks Ritter who to play next on the show -- Ritter says Johnny Cash -- Wildwood Flower (Johnny Cash) [record excerpt] (incomplete) -- Ritter says how he is a Johnny Cash and Mother Maybelle fan -- Ralph Emery and Ritter talk about Charlie Rich -- Emery and Ritter talk about Jerry Reid (incomplete) -- Emery talks about Ritter's 30th anniversary album -- Ritter tells a story about the tune Green Grow The Lilacs -- Ritter talks about the term Gringo -- Green Grow The Lilacs (Tex Ritter) [record excerpt] -- Emery and Ritter talk about Don Gibson briefly -- Emery and Ritter talk about the Statler Brothers and their western film collection -- Whatever Happened To Randolph Scott (Statler Brothers) [record excerpt] -- Ritter talks about a saying from his hometown that inspired the tune Tenaha, Timpson, Bobo, And Blair -- Tenaha, Timpson, Bobo, And Blair (Tex Ritter) [record excerpt] -- Closing statements (Ralph Emery and Tex Ritter) -- Opening statements (Ralph Emery and Tex Ritter) -- Ritter talks about recording with Freddie Hart -- Emery asks about a story where Ritter had a boot thrown at him on tour -- Ritter tells the story, he threw one shoe back, and delivered the other in person, on the young mans head -- Ritter talks about doing children's records -- Froggy Went A Courtin' (Tex Ritter) [record excerpt] -- Emery talks about hearing one of Ritter's tunes on Captain Kangaroo -- Ritter talks about Bob Luman -- Holiday Inn plug (Ralph Emery) -- Ritter talks about Ferlin Husky -- Ritter and Emery talk about older record formats and making children's records -- Ritter talks about recording Hillbilly Heaven -- Hillbilly Heaven (Tex Ritter) -- Ritter talks about the meaning of the word Hillbilly and how he does not like it as a derogatory term -- Ritter introduces the next record -- [Unidentified] talks -- Closing statements (Ralph Emery and Tex Ritter -- Steel Guitar Rag (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Johnny Ryan introduces Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band -- Opening theme -- Leon McAuliffe talks -- Eighth Of January (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Gates tires commercial (Johnny Ryan) -- Tulsa Straight Ahead (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Johnny Ryan reads off birthdays and song requests -- Smoke! Smoke! Smoke! (That Cigarette) (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Johnny Ryan announces the band's appearance schedule -- I'll Hold You In My Heart (Till I Can Hold You In My Arms) (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Gates tires commercial (Johnny Ryan) -- [Unidentified tune] (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Smooth Sailing (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Closing statement (Johnny Ryan) -- [Unidentified tune] -- Jambalaya (On The Bayou) (Johnny Ryan vocals, Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) -- Johnny Ryan talks -- Rubber Dolly (Leon McAuliffe and his Western Swing Band) (incomplete)
